Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: BIOMAPS Control of Spindle Positioning and Cytokinesis

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Cells typically divide at a specific, predictable location. Positioning of the cell division plane in cytokinesis is a fundamental and universal cellular process that has broad relevance to cell morphogenesis, development, tissue architecture, and stem cells. The aims of this research are to determine the molecular mechanisms governing this process. This project utilizes the sea urchin embryo as a potent animal cell model for symmetric cell division. Cell division site determination involves multiple processes. The cell initially positions and orients the nucleus in late interphase along a reproducible axis relative to its cell shape. In this process, the nucleus must somehow sense the shape of the cell. The axis of the interphase nucleus sets the position of the spindle in mitosis, which then specifies the site of cleavage in cytokinesis. The project will focus on the mechanisms of how the nucleus is positioned, how cell shape is sensed, and how the spindle signals to the cortex to specify the division plane. The researchers have recently developed a powerful new approach to study the effect of cell geometry in a systematic manner by manipulating the shape of sea urchin cells by introducing them into micro-fabricated chambers of different shapes (such as rectangles, triangles, etc. The project will include live cell experiments focusing on the identifying the location of and specific molecular motor responsible for nuclear positioning coupled with computational modeling of how the division plane is determined in cells manipulated into different shapes.

Broader Impacts: The researchers continue longstanding efforts to increase the diversity of scientists by broadening participation of underrepresented minorities in science. Efforts will be directed both in the laboratory and in national activities. The PI is a cell biologist who is also a Native American (Cherokee) who has a long record of involvement in working with a diverse pool of students and in national programmatic efforts. The researchers share a laboratory at the Marine Biology Laboratory, Woods Hole for about two months each summer where they host undergraduates (mostly from underrepresented groups) recruited nationally at the Society for Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS) annual conference, from Boston College, and from the NSF funded REU summer program at the MBL. These students are mentored to participate in a number of activities whose aim is to better equip them, should they choose to pursue a scientific career. At the national level, the PI is continuing in a leadership role in programs whose goal is to increase the diversity of scientists including leading NSF supported efforts for SACNAS, for the American Society for Cell Biology and serving in a regular capacity to effect policy change, evaluate programs, and contribute to national activities by service to the AAAS, the NSF, and to colleges, universities and scientific societies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research focused on how cells decide how to control their cell division machinery.  Specifically, we have used dividing eggs as a model system to analyze how the mitotic spindle and how the sperm center in the cell.  Such centration is critical for assuring that the mitotic spindle is positioned accurately as the accurate positioning of the mitotic spindle specifies the division plane.  We have attempted to combine in vitro experimentation with mathematical modeling in an attempt to generate models that will be applicable to other cell types.  Our work has brought in collaborators with varying expertise in both experimental techniques and use of other organisms.  We have studied the organization of the machinery that is used to divide the cell in half (cytokinesis, the separation of the cell) after the completion of mitosis (the duplication and separation of the chromosomes).  We have found that regardless of the asymmetric initial shape of a cell, the contractile muscle-like belt that separates the cell after mitosis assumes the initial cell shape but transitions to a circular shape, which is the lowest energy configuration.  We have also studied asymmetric cell divisions, which are essential to normal development in embryos, in a collaboration with a scientist in France taking advantage of his use of an egg of a near relative of vertebrates.  We have found that the mitotic apparatus becomes asymmetric and thus triggers an asymmetric cell division.  Recently, our work has focused on how the fertilizing sperm migrates, using an astral array of microtubules, to capture the female pronucleus in an egg.  While there have been in vitro reports of use of the astral microtubules to push an aster forward, our work provides the first documented example of this mechanism in a cell. Our work has been published in peer reviewed journals and has been presented at international meetings.  Complementing work in the laboratory the PI, Dr. Burgess, has continued his longstanding work on training, mentoring and leading programs to diversify the STEM pipeline. At the local level, he continued to train URM undergraduates, served as one of the organizers for the Boston area Society for Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science Regional Meeting of over 250 participants, served as faculty advisor for the Boston College SACNAS student chapter, taught a Boston College course on the Biology of Race and Health Disparities, and gave local lectures on Native Americans in science.  At the national level, the PI continued to serve SACNAS as an elected member of its Board, by participating on SACNAS grants, by serving on the SACNAS Native American Affairs and Finance Committees. He served as Chair-elect of the Section of Biological Sciences for AAAS, and lecture at and advise universities on STEM diversity efforts.
